{{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = Pankritio Stadium | nickname = | image = [[File:Pagkritio.jpg|320px]] | fullname = | location = [[Heraklion]], [[Crete]], [[Greece]] | coordinates = {{Coord|35|20|12|N|25|6|22|E|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = 1990 | built = December 31, 2003 | opened = August 11, 2004 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Hellenic Olympic Committee]] | operator = City of [[Heraklion]] | surface = [[Grass]] | scoreboard = [[LED]] | construction_cost = [[Euro|€]] 50,000,000 | architect = Vassilis Floudas & Associates | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[Ergotelis F.C.|Ergotelis]] (2004−)
'''Former Tenants''':
[[OFI Crete F.C.|OFI Crete]] (2006−2009)
[[Greece national football team|Greece]] (2019–) | seating_capacity = 26,240{{cite web |url=http://www.olympicproperties.gr/contents_en.asp?id=98 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-09-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100921153802/http://www.olympicproperties.gr/contents_en.asp?id=98 |archivedate=2010-09-21 |df= }} | dimensions = 105 x 68 m }} The '''Pankritio Stadium''' ({{lang-el|Παγκρήτιο Στάδιο}}, ''Pagkritio Stadio'' literally:''Pancretan Stadium'') is a multi-purpose sports [[stadium]] located in [[Heraklion]] on the island of [[Crete]]. It was completed on 31 December 2003, and officially opened on August 11, 2004. As one of the most modern sports venues in [[Greece]] at the time, it was used as one of the [[association football|football]] venues to host matches of the [[Football at the 2004 Summer Olympics|2004 Summer Olympics Football tournament]]. It has a capacity of 26,240 seats, and is currently the home ground of [[Heraklion]] [[association football|football]] club [[Ergotelis F.C.|Ergotelis]], and on occasion, the [[Greece national football team|Greek national football team]]. ==Location== The Pankritio Stadium is located in [[Heraklion]], at the Lido district to the west of the city center. It has been built about 50 meters from the island coast, and is neighbored by the [[Lido Indoor Hall]] and the city's outdoor pool venue,{{cite web|publisher=stadia.gr|title=Παγκρήτιο Στάδιο | language=Greek |url=http://www.stadia.gr/pankritio/pankritio-gr.html|date=}} of which the whole district is named after ([[Lido]]). ==History== The stadium broke ground sometime during the late 80s, however construction work was never completed on time, and was eventually indefinitely postponed. Once [[Greece]] won the bid to host the [[2004 Summer Olympics]], construction of the stadium was finally picked up once again in 2001. It was eventually completed on 31 December 2003. The total construction cost was estimated at €50.000.000. The new stadium was officially opened on 11 August 2004, to host an international [[exhibition game|friendly game]] between [[Greece national football team|Greece]] and [[Switzerland national football team|Switzerland]].[http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/2004/or2004b.pdf 2004 Summer Olympic venues.] Volume 2. p. 324. Due to its size, age and ranking, the Pankritio was selected as one of the football venues of the [[Football at the 2004 Summer Olympics|2004 Summer Olympics Football Tournament]], hosting in total 10 matches (5 [[Football at the 2004 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|men's Group Stage matches]], 2 [[Football at the 2004 Summer Olympics – Women's tournament|women's Group Stage]] matches, one [[Football at the 2004 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|men's Quarterfinals match]], one [[Football at the 2004 Summer Olympics – Women's tournament|women's Quarterfinals match]] and one [[Football at the 2004 Summer Olympics – Women's tournament|women's Semi-Final match]]).{{cite web|publisher=Heraklion Sports Development A.E. O.T.A.|title=Παγκρήτιο Στάδιο | language=Greek |url=http://www.aahaeota.gr/node/189|date=}} After the tournament, the stadium was rented out, and has since been used as a training and home ground of the city's [[association football|football]] club [[Ergotelis F.C.|Ergotelis]], and occasionally also by the [[Greece national football team|Greek national football team]]. In 2006, the Pankritio hosted the [[2005–06 Greek Cup]] Final, the first to be played in [[Heraklion]] since 1931. Although primarily considered a [[association football|football]] stadium, the Pankritio, has also been used to host major [[Sport of athletics|athletics]] events, such as the [[Athens Grand Prix Tsiklitiria|2004 Tsiklitiria]] annual [[IAAF World Challenge]] meeting and the [[2015 European Team Championships]] First League. The stadium has also been used for a number of music concerts, most notably hosting [[Deep Purple]] and [[Vasilis Papakonstantinou]] on May 6, 2011.{{cite web|publisher=rocking.gr|title=Deep Purple / Βασίλης Παπακωνσταντίνου και στην Κρήτη | language=Greek |url=http://www.rocking.gr/news/Deep_Purple__Basilis_Papakwnstantinou_kai_stin_Kriti/9474|date=11 April 2011}} == Facilities == The Pankritio Stadium sports complex features in total two football grounds built to international standards (main stadium and training ground), an 8-lane track, an auxiliary 6-lane track, an indoor gym and swimming pool, multi-purpose halls for [[boxing]], [[wrestling]], [[fencing]], [[dance]], [[Olympic weightlifting|weightlifting]], [[shooting]] and [[tae kwon do]], a [[rowing]] simulator and a physiotherapy room with sauna and hot tub. Additionally, the stadium features seminar meeting rooms, a dining room, and a showroom featuring exhibits from the [[2004 Summer Olympics]] and [[2011 Special Olympics World Summer Games|2011 Special Olympics]]. The complex is neighbored by the city's outdoor swimming pool and the [[Lido Indoor Hall]]. == Tenants == The stadium has been used as the home ground of [[Football League (Greece)|Football League]] football team [[Ergotelis F.C.|Ergotelis]], since its opening in 2004, as their traditional home turf [[Nikos Kazantzakis Stadium]] was declared unfit for use in official matches at any level of the [[Greek football league system]] since 2004. Between 2006 and 2009, the stadium was also used by [[Ergotelis F.C.|Ergotelis]]' rival [[OFI Crete F.C.|OFI]], before they returned to their original home ground, [[Theodoros Vardinogiannis Stadium]]. On occasion, the Pankritio has also hosted home games of the [[Greece national football team|Greek national football team]], notably attracting large numbers of spectators from all over the [[Crete|island]]. == Records == Τhe stadium attendance record and first ever sold-out event was set on 20 February 2005, in a [[Superleague Greece|Superleague]] match between [[Ergotelis F.C.|Ergotelis]] and reigning champions [[Olympiacos F.C.|Olympiacos]] with 27,950 tickets being sold.{{cite web|publisher=gazzetta.gr|title=Τα sold out των ελληνικών γηπέδων (Greek) |url=http://www.gazzetta.gr/node/173593|date=7 November 2008}} The result was a 2−1 victory for the home team. ==2004 Summer Olympics== Pankritio Stadium hosted six games of the [[Football at the 2004 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|men's football tournament at the 2004 Summer Olympics]], and four games of the [[Football at the 2004 Summer Olympics – Women's tournament|women's Olympic Football tournament]]. ===Men's tournament=== {{anchor}} {{clear}} {|class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; width:100%;" |- !Date !Time !Team No. 1 !Res. !Team No. 2 !Round !Attendance |- |11 August 2004||20:30|| {{flagicon|Tunisia}} [[Tunisia national under-23 football team|Tunisia]] ||style="text-align:center;"| 1–1 || {{flagicon|Australia}} [[Tunisia national under-23 football team|Australia]] ||[[Football at the 2004 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament#Group C|Group C]]||style="text-align:center;"| 15,757{{cite web |url=https://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/mensolympic/athens2004/matches/round=8690/match=37152/index.html |title=Match report – Group C – Tunisia - [[File:Scudetto.svg|thumb|150px|The ''scudetto'']] The '''''scudetto''''' ([[Italian language|Italian]] for: "little shield") is a decoration worn by Italian sports clubs that win the annual championship of their respective sport in the previous season.
The ''scudetto'' was created in the 1920s to honour the [[List of Italian football champions|winner]] of the national association football league (which eventually become [[Serie A]] in 1929) and the first ever team to wear it was [[Genoa C.F.C.]] in 1924.
Later, it was adopted by the teams of other sports.
== Origin == [[File:Andrea Marcato 2006.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Andrea Marcato]], a rugby union player, wearing the ''scudetto'' won with [[Benetton Rugby|Benetton Treviso]] the season before]] Sources generally agree that the inventor of the ''scudetto'' was the Italian poet and playwright [[Gabriele D'Annunzio]]. In his youth, D'Annunzio was a keen follower of football and in 1887 he bought in [[London]] a leather ball from the same manufacturer that used to supply the [[English Football League|Football League]]<ref name="Gazzetta">{{cite news|author=Paolo Pierangelodate=8 April 2013|title=150 anni di D'Annunzio, l'ideatore dello scudetto sulle maglie da gioco|trans-title=D'Annunzio's 150th Birthday: He Was the Inventor of the ''scudetto'' on Sports Jerseys|url=http://www.fantagazzetta.com/blogs/18_04_2013/150-anni-di-dannunziolideatore-dello-scudetto-sulle-maglie-da-gioco-170340|language=italian|newspaper=[[la Gazzetta dello Sport]]|location=[[Milan]]|accessdate=9 December 2016}}</ref> and used to play football with his friends on the beach of [[Pescara]], his native place.<ref name="Gazzetta"/>
Later in 1920, once the former Austro-Hungarian city of [[Rijeka|Fiume]] (now the [[Croatia]]n [[Rijeka]]) was annexed to Italy, D'Annunzio proposed that the local football team wear on its jerseys a small shield with the [[Flag of Italy|tricolore]] ([[green]], [[white]] and [[red]]) to symbolize the Italian sovereignty over the city.<ref name="Gazzetta"/><ref name="Focus">{{cite news|url=http://www.focus.it/cultura/storia/inventore-scudetto-d-annunzio|title=Chi ha inventato lo Scudetto?|trans-title=Who Invented the ''scudetto''?|date=25 April 2016|author=Roberto Graziosi|accessdate=9 December 2016|newspaper=[[Focus (Italian magazine)|Focus]]}}</ref>
In 1924, the [[Italian Football Federation]] approved the decision to honour the defending champion allowing them to wear the ''scudetto'' on their jerseys. Since then, the ''scudetto'' has become the symbol of the defending champions of every sports league in Italy.
The Italian [[Top12|rugby union championship]] which started in 1928 also adopted the ''scudetto'' on the champion team's jerseys and so did the other team sports in Italy.

revision.text:
{{about|the football stadium in Florence|the stadium in Siena|Stadio Artemio Franchi - Montepaschi Arena}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2017}} {{Infobox venue| stadium_name = Stadio Comunale Artemio Franchi | nickname = Stadio Comunale| image = [[File:Soccer in Florence, Italy, 2007.jpg|320px]] | location = [[Florence]], [[Italy]] | opened = 13 September 1931 | renovated = 1990 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Municipality of [[Florence]]| operator = | surface = Grass| construction_cost = | architect = [[Pier Luigi Nervi]]| former_names = Stadio Comunale | tenants = [[ACF Fiorentina]] (1931-present)
[[Italy national football team]] (selected matches) | seating_capacity = 43,147http://it.violachannel.tv/vc13-stadio-franchi.html | }} The '''Stadio Artemio Franchi''' is a [[football (soccer)|football]] [[stadium]] in [[Florence]], [[Italy]]. It is currently the home of [[ACF Fiorentina]]. The stadium was temporarily noticed as the host of Italy's Six Nations matches from [[2012 Six Nations Championship|2012]].[http://sport.scotsman.com/rugby/Italians-in-new-threat-to.6746124.jp][http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/rugby_union/12941136.stm BBC Sport] The old nickname of the stadium was "Comunale." When it was first constructed, it was known as the '''Stadio Giovanni Berta''', [[:it:Giovanni Berta|after a Florentine fascist]]. The stadium was officially opened on 13 September 1931 with a match between Fiorentina and [[Admira Wien]] (1-0), though it took until 1932 for the stadium to be completely finished and currently holds 47,282.http://www.stadiumguide.com/artemiofranchi/ The architect is [[Pier Luigi Nervi]]{{cite book | first=Guido | last=Zucconi | year=1995 | title=Florence: An Architectural Guide | edition=2001 Reprint | publisher=Arsenale Editrice | location=San Giovanni Lupatoto (Vr) | isbn=88-7743-147-4 | page=131}} (known for the [[Nervi Hall]] in the [[Vatican City|Vatican]]) and it is one of the most relevant examples of 20th-century architecture in the city.[http://www.firenzemadeintuscany.com/en/arts/articles/florence-rationalist/ ''Florence Rationalist''] The stadium is built entirely of reinforced concrete with a 70-meter (230 ft) tower that bears the stadium's flagstaff. The tower is called the "Tower of Marathon". Around the base of the tower, spiral ramps lead from the ground floor to the upper edge of the grandstand. It hosted some of the matches of the [[1934 World Cup]], as well as [[Football at the 1960 Summer Olympics|football]] preliminaries for the [[1960 Summer Olympics]] in [[Rome]].[http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1960/OR1960v1.pdf 1960 Summer Olympics official report.] Volume 1. pp. 85-6. In 1945, it hosted the [[Spaghetti Bowl (American football)|Spaghetti Bowl]] between American service teams. The stadium was originally called the "Comunale" but was renamed after the former [[Italian Football Federation|FIGC]] president, [[Artemio Franchi]], in 1991. The stadium itself underwent renovations for the [[1990 FIFA World Cup]] which included removing the running track and increasing the [[seating capacity]]. At the World Cup, the ground hosted three matches in Group A and [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]]'s penalty shootout win over [[Yugoslavia national football team|Yugoslavia]] in the quarter-finals.{{cite web|title=1990 Match Schedule|url=http://www.planetworldcup.com/CUPS/1990/wc90index.html|publisher=PlanetWorldCup.com|accessdate=10 March 2014}} The official record attendance is 58,271 on 25 November 1984, at a [[Serie A]] match between [[ACF Fiorentina|Fiorentina]] and [[F.C. Internazionale Milano|Internazionale]]. ==Concerts== [[David Bowie]] performed at the stadium during his [[Glass Spider Tour]] on 9 June 1987. [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] performed, with [[Level 42]] as her opening act, the final show of her [[Who's That Girl World Tour]] at the stadium on 6 September 1987. This performance was filmed & later released as a [[VHS]] & later as a [[DVD]], titled ''[[Ciao, Italia! – Live from Italy]]''. She performed at the stadium again 25 years later on 16 June 2012 to a sold out crowd of 42,434 people during her [[MDNA Tour]] . [[Bruce Springsteen]] performed on 8 June 2003 at the stadium during his [[The Rising Tour]] and on 10 June 2012 for the [[Wrecking Ball World Tour]], in front of 42,658 people. It rained for the entire duration of the 2012 concert. On Sunday 23 June 2013, the stadium hosted a Jovanotti concert. Jovanotti is from [[Cortona]], a city relatively close to [[Firenze|Florence]], and many members of his family were in the audience including his wife, child and parents. ==National team - football== The [[Italy national football team]] has played at the stadium, the first occasion being on 7 May 1933 in a 2-0 win over [[Czechoslovakia national football team|Czechoslovakia]]. The national team played only one game there between 1982 and 2006; a 2-0 friendly win against Mexico on 20 January 1993. On 1 March 2006, they played a friendly against [[Germany national football team|Germany]] and won 4-1. The stadium hosted two matches in [[Euro 2012]] qualifying: a 5-0 win over the [[Faroe Islands national football team|Faroe Islands]], and a 1-0 win over [[Slovenia national football team|Slovenia]] on 6 September 2011 which was its most recent international hosting.{{cite web|title=Stadio Comunale Artemio Franchi|url=http://eu-football.info/_venue.php?id=1790|publisher=EU-Football.info|accessdate=10 March 2014}} During the match with Faroe Islands, [[Fabio Quagliarella]] (a member of Juventus at the time) scored a goal. Because Fiorentina fans have such a strong rivalry with Juventus, the fans at the stadium booed Quagliarella. ==National team - rugby== {{see also|Italy national rugby union team}} The stadium has also hosted international [[rugby union]] matches. [[Italy national rugby union team|Italy]] played [[Australia national rugby union team|Australia]] on 20 November 2010, losing by a score of 14-32.{{cite web | publisher=federugby.it|title=ITALIA v AUSTRALIA A FIRENZE IL 20 NOVEMBRE|url=http://www.federugby.it/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1745:italia-v-australia-a-firenze-il-20-novembre-il-vice-sindaco-nardella-una-grande-occasioneq&catid=109:italia&Itemid=415|accessdate=22 July 2010}} {{cite web | publisher=theaustralian.com.au|title=Wallabies back on course with 32-14 win over Italy|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/sport/wallabies-back-on-course-with-32-14-win-over-italy/story-fn6aueer-1225957652615|accessdate=21 November 2010}} Italy won a famous victory against [[South Africa national rugby union team|South Africa]] on 19 November 2016, beating the Springboks for the first time in their history. The final score was 20-18. ==Mass UFO Sighting of 1954== On 27 October 1954, a reserve game between Fiorentina and nearby rivals Pistoiese was under way at the Stadio Artemio Franchi when a group of [[UFO]]s traveling at high speed abruptly stopped over the stadium. The stadium became silent as the crowd of around 10,000 spectators witnessed the event and described the UFOs as cigar shaped. It was suggested that the most likely explanation was that the silk of mass migrating spiders had agglomerated high in the atmosphere.{{cite web|title=The day UFOs hovered over Fiorentina's Stadio Artemio Franchi|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/20917594}}{{cite web|title=The day UFOs stopped play|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-29342407}} ==1934 FIFA World Cup== The stadium was one of the venues of the [[1934 FIFA World Cup]], and held the following matches: {{clear}} {| width="100%" class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align: left;" |- !Date !Team #1 !Res. !Team #2 !Round !Attendance !Referee |- |27 May 1934||{{fb|GER|1933}}||style="text-align:center;"|5–2||{{fb|BEL}}||First Round||8,000||Francesco Mattea (Italy) |- |31 May 1934||{{fb|ITA|1861}}||style="text-align:center;"|1–1||{{fb|ESP|1931}}||Quarter Finals||35,000||[[Louis Baert]] (Belgium) |- |1 June 1934||{{fb|ITA|1861}}||style="text-align:center;"|1–0||{{fb|ESP|1931}}||Quarter Finals (Replay)||43,000||[[René Mercet]] (Switzerland) |- |} ==1990 FIFA World Cup== The stadium was one of the venues of the [[1990 FIFA World Cup]], and held the following matches: {{clear}} {| width="100%" class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align: left;" |- !Date !Team #1 !Res. !Team #2 !Round |- |10 June 1990||{{fb|USA}}||style="text-align:center;"|1–5||{{fb|TCH}}||Group A |- |15 June 1990||{{fb|AUT}}||style="text-align:center;"|0–1||{{fb|TCH}}||Group A |- |19 June 1990||{{fb|AUT}}||style="text-align:center;"|2–1||{{fb|USA}}||Group A |- |30 June 1990||{{fb|ARG}}||style="text-align:center;"|0–0 (3–2 on [[Penalty shootout|penalties]])||{{fb|YUG}}||Quarter-finals revision.text:
{{About|a type of [[horse race]]|the athletics event|Steeplechase (athletics)}} {{Infobox sport | name = Steeplechasing | image = Steeplechase (1257926029).jpg | alt = | imagesize = | caption = A steeplechase race | union = Usually governed by assorted national organizations | nickname = | first = | firstlabel = | region = Predominantly [[United Kingdom]], [[Ireland]], [[France]], [[North America]], [[Australia]] | registered = | clubs = | contact = No | team = Individual | mgender = Yes | type = Outdoor | equipment = [[Horse]] | venue = Turf racecourse with obstacles | olympic = | paralympic =
}}
A '''steeplechase''' is a distance [[horse race]] in which competitors are required to jump diverse fence and ditch obstacles. Steeplechasing is primarily conducted in [[Ireland]] (where it originated), the [[United Kingdom]], [[Canada]], [[United States]], [[Australia]] and [[France]]. The name is derived from early races in which orientation of the course was by reference to a [[Church (building)|church]] [[steeple]], jumping fences and ditches and generally traversing the many intervening obstacles in the countryside.
Modern usage of the term "steeplechase" differs between countries. In Ireland and the United Kingdom, it refers only to races run over large, fixed obstacles, in contrast to "[[Hurdling (horse race)|hurdle]]" races where the obstacles are much smaller. The collective term "jump racing" or "[[National Hunt racing]]" is used when referring to steeplechases and hurdle races collectively (although, properly speaking, National Hunt racing also includes some [[flat racing|flat races]]). Elsewhere in the world, "steeplechase" is used to refer to any race that involves jumping obstacles.
The most famous steeplechase in the world is the [[Grand National]] run annually at [[Aintree Racecourse]], in [[Liverpool]], since its inception in 1836 (the official race was held three years later), which in 2014 offered a prize fund of [[Pound sterling|£]]1 million.
== History == [[File:Anonymous.The Lads of the Village.JPG|thumb|"The lads from the village" - the first recorded English steeplechase 1830]] The steeplechase originated in Ireland in the 18th century as an analogue to [[Cross-country equestrianism|cross-country]] thoroughbred horse races which went from [[Steeple (architecture)|church steeple]] to church steeple, hence "steeplechase". The first steeplechase is said to have been the result of a wager in 1752 between Cornelius O'Callaghan and Edmund Blake, racing four miles (6.4 km) cross-country from St John's Church in [[Buttevant]] to St Mary's Church (Church of Ireland) in [[Doneraile]], in [[County Cork|Cork]], [[Ireland]].{{sfn|Barrett|1995|p=9}} An account of the race was believed to have been in the library of the O'Briens of [[Dromoland Castle]]. Most of the earlier steeplechases were contested cross-country rather than on a track, and resembled English [[Cross-country equestrianism|cross country]] as it exists today. The first recorded steeplechase over a prepared track with fences was run at [[Bedford Racecourse|Bedford]] in 1810, although a race had been run at [[Newmarket Racecourse|Newmarket]] in 1794 over a mile (1600 m) with five-foot (1.5 m) bars every quarter mile (400 m).<ref name="Stevens 103">Stevens, Peter, History of the National Hunt Chase 1860–2010, p. 103</ref> and the first recorded steeplechase of any kind in England took place in [[Leicestershire]] in 1792, when three horses raced the eight miles from Barkby Holt to Billesdon Coplow and back.{{sfn|Barrett|1995|p=10}}
The first recorded hurdle race took place at [[Durdham Down]] near [[Bristol]] in 1821. There were 5 hurdles on the mile long course, and the race was run in three heats.{{sfn|Barrett|1995|p=12}}
The first recognised English National Steeplechase took place on Monday 8 March 1830. The {{convert|4|mi|km|adj=on}} race, organised by Thomas Coleman of [[St Albans]], was run from Bury Orchard, [[Harlington, Bedfordshire|Harlington]] in Bedfordshire to the Obelisk in Wrest Park, Bedfordshire. The winner was Captain Macdowall on "The Wonder", owned by Lord Ranelagh, who won in a time of 16 minutes 25 seconds. Report of the event appeared in the May and July editions of ''Sporting Magazine'' in 1830.{{citation needed|date=April 2014}}
==Steeplechasing by country==
===Europe===
====Great Britain and Ireland==== {{further|National Hunt racing}} In Great Britain and Ireland, "steeplechase" only refers to one branch of jump racing.
Collectively, Great Britain and Ireland account for over 50% of all jump races worldwide, carding 4,800 races over fences in 2008. Jump racing in Great Britain and Ireland is officially known as [[National Hunt racing]].
====France==== French jump racing is similar to British and Irish National Hunt races, with a few notable differences. Hurdles are not collapsible, being more akin to small brush fences. Chases often have large fences called bullfinches, a large hedge up to {{convert|8|ft|m|abbr=on}} tall that horses have to jump through rather than over. There are also a larger number of cross-country chases where horses have to jump up and down banks, gallop through water, jump over stone walls as well as jump normal chasing fences.
Unlike in most countries where the thoroughbred is almost exclusively used for jump racing, many of the horses in French jump racing are [[AQPS]] (Autre Que Pur Sang), a breed of horse developed in France crossing thoroughbreds with saddle horses and other local breeds.
[[Auteuil Hippodrome|Auteuil]] in Paris is perhaps the best known racecourse in France for French jump racing.
====Czech Republic==== The [[Velká pardubická]] Steeplechase in Pardubice in the Czech Republic is the location of one of the longest steeplechase races in Europe. The first Velka Pardubice Steeplechase was held on 5 November 1874 and it has been hosted annually since.<ref>[http://becher123.webs.com/thecourse.htm Velka Pardubicka Steeplechase] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101110034859/http://becher123.webs.com/thecourse.htm |date=2010-11-10 }} Retrieved 2010-10-12</ref>
===Rest of the world===
====United States==== [[File:Civil War steeplechase2.jpg|thumb|right|325px|[[Saint Patrick's Day]] celebration in the [[Army of the Potomac]]. Depicts a steeplechase race among the [[Irish Brigade (U.S.)|Irish Brigade]], 17 March 1863, by [[Edwin Forbes]]. Digitally restored.]]
In the United States, there are two forms of steeplechasing (or jumps racing): hurdle and timber.
Hurdle races occur almost always over the National fences, standardized plastic and steel fences that are 52 inches tall, with traditional natural fences of packed pine (Springdale Race Course in [[Camden, South Carolina]]) and live hedges ([[Montpelier (Orange, Virginia)|Montpelier,]] Virginia) in use on a few courses. National fences stand 52 inches tall at the highest point, but are mostly made of synthetic "brush" that can be brushed through (much like the synthetic fences now used in other countries). The hurdle horse is trained to jump in as much of a regular stride as possible. This allows the horse to maintain its speed upon landing. Since it is not always possible to meet a fence in stride, the horses are also schooled in how to jump out of stride. An out of stride jump can decrease a horse's speed drastically. Hurdle races are commonly run at distances of 2–3 miles (3–5 km). Hurdle races occur at steeplechase meets mainly in the Mid-Atlantic and Southeast and on the turf courses of several racetracks – Saratoga, Colonial Downs, Penn National, Monmouth Park and others.
Timber racing is conducted over solid and immovable wooden rail fences that, in the most extreme case, may reach five feet (1.5 m) high. The distances are longer, ranging from three to four miles (6 km), and the jumping effort required of the horse is much different. Because of the size of the fences and their solid and unyielding construction, a timber horse is trained to jump with an arc, unlike a hurdle racer. An important factor in success at timber racing is for the horse to land in stride, so that it can carry its speed forward on the flat part of the race course. This is harder than in hurdle races because the nature of the obstacle being jumped. If a horse hits a timber fence hard enough, it can bring it almost to a complete stop. Most notable US timber races include the [[Maryland Hunt Cup]] in [[Glyndon, Maryland|Glyndon]] and the [[Virginia Gold Cup]] in [[The Plains, Virginia|The Plains]]. Timber races currently are not held at any major US tracks (since the fences are not portable) but can be found at almost all steeplechase meets.
American jump racing happens in 11 states: Georgia, South Carolina, North Carolina, Tennessee, Kentucky, Virginia, Maryland, Pennsylvania, Delaware, New Jersey and New York. The [[National Steeplechase Association]] is the official sanctioning body of American jump racing. ''Steeplechase Times'' newspaper covers the sport.<ref>''[http://www.steeplechasetimes.com Steeplechase Times]''</ref>
[[Thomas Hitchcock]] (1860–1941) is known as the father of American steeplechasing. In the late 1800s, he built a steeplechase training center on his {{convert|3000|acre|km2|adj=on}} property in [[Aiken, South Carolina]] and trained horses imported from England. No less important are the contributions by fellow Aiken seasonal resident [[F. Ambrose Clark]]. Clark held many important chases on his Brookville (Long Island) estate, Broad Hollow, in the 1920s and 1930s. Ford Conger Field was built by F. Ambrose Clark and is the site of the annual Aiken Steeplechase, a part of the Triple Crown in March. The first Steeplechase Meet in Aiken was held March 14, 1930 in Hitchcock Woods. In addition to the Aiken Steeplechase, South Carolina is also home to the Colonial Cup and the Carolina Cup, which is the largest event on the circuit. Both of these races are held in [[Camden, South Carolina]].
The Virginia Gold Cup is also among the oldest steeplechase races in the United States, with its first running in 1922. Up until recently, the Gold Cup was a four-mile (6 km) long hurdle race. The length of this race prompted many jokes - such as the jockeys putting marbles in their mouth and spitting one out each lap to keep track of what lap they had completed. Since the Gold Cup moved to the present course, it has been changed into a timber race with a very large purse. Every first Saturday in May, more than 50,000 spectators gather at [[Great Meadow]] near The Plains, Virginia (45 miles (72 km) west of Washington, DC). The {{convert|4|mi|km|adj=on}} grass course with {{convert|4|ft|m|adj=on}} high timber fences is often referred to as the "crown jewel of steeplechasing."
Tennessee State Historian Walter T. Durham's book ''Grasslands'' relates the history of the Southern Grasslands Hunt and Racing Foundation, a group that organized the first international steeplechase held on U.S. soil 80 years ago at Grassland Downs, a {{convert|24|sqmi|km2|adj=on}} course located in Gallatin, TN between 1929 and 1932.
In addition to holding an inaugural race in 1930, two international steeplechases were held at Grasslands in 1930 and 1931. The winners were awarded a gold trophy designed by [[King Alfonso XIII]] of Spain.<ref>tennessean.com [http://www.tennessean.com/article/20101111/GALLATIN01/101110151/Durham-s-book-shares-oft-forgotten-part-of-Gallatin-s-history Gallatin's history]</ref>
The [[Iroquois Steeplechase]] event is held in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]], [[Tennessee]]. Beginning in 1941, with one year off during [[World War II]], the race has been run continuously at Percy Warner Park on a course inspired by Marcellus Frost and designed by William duPont.
The Queens Cup Steeplechase is held annually on the last Saturday of April at [[Brooklandwood]], a farm and estate in [[Mineral Springs, North Carolina]], about {{convert|20|mi|km}} from [[Charlotte]].
The [[Breeders' Cup Grand National Steeplechase]] (formerly known as the [[American Grand National]]) is held each October at the [[Far Hills Races]] in [[Far Hills, New Jersey]] and draws about 50,000 spectators for a single day race-meet. It is the richest event in American steeplechasing with a purse of $500,000.
During the 1940s and 50s, the [[Broad Hollow Steeplechase Handicap]], the [[Brook National Steeplechase Handicap]] and the American Grand National were regarded as American steeplechasing's [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|Triple Crown]].
[[Kentucky Downs]] near [[Franklin, Kentucky]] (originally Dueling Grounds Race Course) was built in 1990 as a steeplechase track, with a kidney-shaped turf circuit. At its inception, the track offered some of the richest purses in the history of American steeplechase including a $750,000 race. The track has undergone numerous ownership changes, with steeplechase races playing an on-and-off role (mainly off) in the track's limited live race meets.
The Stoneybrook Steeplechase was initiated in [[Southern Pines, North Carolina]] on a private farm owned by [[Michael G. Walsh]] in 1949 and was held annually in the spring until 1996, with attendance near 20,000. It resumed as an annual spring event at the new [[Carolina Horse Park]] in 2001, but was discontinued after 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chronofhorse.com/article/carolina-horse-park-no-longer-hosting-stoneybrook-steeplechase|title=Carolina Horse Park No Longer Hosting Stoneybrook Steeplechase|date=November 22, 2016|publisher=Chronicle of the Horse}}</ref>
The [[New York Turf Writers Cup]] is held each year at [[Saratoga Race Course]], attracting the best steeplechasing horses in the U.S.
====Australia==== [[File:Steeplechasing (AUS).jpg|thumb|250px|A steeplechase at [[Five Dock, New South Wales|Five Dock, NSW.]]]] [[Australia]] has a long history of jumps racing which was introduced by British settlers. In the late 20th century, the northern states of [[Queensland]] and [[New South Wales]] shut down jumps racing, while Tasmania ceased jumps racing in April 2007 due to economic unfeasibility and a lack of entries.<ref>{{Citation | last =Bourke | first =Tony | title =Tasmania calls end to jumps races | newspaper =The Age | pages = | date =2007-04-28 | url =http://www.theage.com.au/news/horse-racing/tasmania-calls-end-to-jumps-races/2007/04/27/1177459980505.html | location=Melbourne}}</ref>
The jumping season in Australia normally takes place from March until September. (some minor races are held either side of these months). Horses used for steeplechasing are primarily former flat racing horses, rather than horses specifically bred for jumping.
There is an emphasis on safety in Australia which has led to a reduction in the size of obstacles. As jumps races take place at flat racing meetings there is also a need for portable jumps. Most chasing occurs on steeple lanes but also includes parts of the main flat racing track. From Easter to May the major distance races occur: The [[Great Eastern Steeplechase]] is held on Easter Monday at [[Oakbank, South Australia]] drawing crowds of over 100,000, and the [[Grand Annual]], which has the most fences of any steeplechase in the world, is held in May at [[Warrnambool, Victoria|Warrnambool]].
Each state holds its own Grand National race: the most prestigious is the VRC Grand National at [[Flemington Racecourse|Flemington]] run in the winter. The jumping season culminates with the set-weights-and-penalties Hiskens Steeple run at [[Moonee Valley Racecourse|Moonee Valley]]. The Hiskens is regarded as the [[Cox Plate]] of jumps racing.
The most famous Australian horse in the field was [[Crisp (horse)|Crisp]], who was narrowly beaten by the champion [[Red Rum]] in the 1973 English Grand National. Crisp subsequently beat Red Rum at set weights. More recently [[Karasi]] has won the [[Nakayama Grand Jump]], the world's richest jumps race held in [[Japan]], three times.
Jumps racing was set to end in Victoria after the 2010 season.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.theage.com.au/sport/horseracing/jumps-racing-hits-the-wall-20091127-jvol.html | location=Melbourne | work=The Age | title=Jumps racing hits the wall | date=2009-11-27}}</ref> In September 2010, having satisfied a limit on the maximum number of deaths among starting horses, hurdle racing was granted a 3-year extension by Racing Victoria.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.racingvictoria.net.au/news/JR/n_Board_decision_on_Hurdle_and_Steeplechase_Racing.aspx|title=Board decision on Hurdle and Steeplechase Racing|date=2 September 2010|publisher=Racing Victoria}}</ref> A decision regarding steeplechase was postponed until October 2010 when a program for the 2011 season only was granted.<ref>{{cite web|title=One year steeplechase racing program approved|url=http://www.racingvictoria.net.au/news/JR/n_One_year_steeplechase_racing_program_approved.aspx|work=Racing Victoria Jumps Racing website news|publisher=[[Racing Victoria]]|accessdate=11 March 2011|date=7 October 2010}}</ref> Since 2012, both hurdle races and steeplechases have been approved by Racing Victoria.
==Statistics== Number of jumping races by country in 2008.
* [[Great Britain]] : 3,366<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.horseracingintfed.com/wageringDisplay.asp?section=12&CK=E&YR=2008&key=14|title=International Federation of Horseracing Authorities|website=www.horseracingintfed.com}}</ref> * [[France]] : 2,194 * [[Ireland]] : 1,434 * [[United States of America]] : 200 * [[Australia]] : 146 * [[Japan]] : 132<ref>[http://japanracing.jp/_statistics/2015/s04.html] Number of Runners According to Age & Breed (1990-): Thoroughbred Steeplechase Horses</ref> * [[New Zealand]] : 129 * [[Germany]] : 58
==Opposition to jumps racing==
===Australia=== Jumps racing in Australia is only run in Victoria and South Australia.
The NSW government officially shut down jumps racing in 1997 after a bill was put through linked with bird tethering, but by that stage there had not been regular jumps race meetings in NSW since World War II, when it was ceased due to the war efforts, except for a handful of exhibition events on an annual basis in the 1980s.
In 2012, the [[Victoria Racing Club|VRC]] Grand National Steeplechase was worth $250,000 and the [[Grand Annual|Warrnambool Grand Annual Steeplechase]] was worth $252,000.
Jumps racing is opposed in Australia by groups including the [[animal rights]] organisations the [[RSPCA Australia]],<ref>{{Citation |last = Wirth |first = Hugh |title = The case against jumps racing |newspaper = Herald Sun |pages = |date = 2009-05-12 |url = http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0,21985,25465045-5000117,00.html |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090529020956/http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0,21985,25465045-5000117,00.html |archivedate = May 29, 2009 |df = }}</ref> Animals Australia,<ref>{{Citation | last =Animals Australia | first = | title =Call to stop Warrnambool jumps racing Carnival | newspaper = | pages = | date =2009-04-27 | url =http://www.animalsaustralia.org/media/press_releases.php?release=115 }}</ref> and Animal Liberation (South Australia),<ref>{{Citation | last =Animal Liberation | first = | title =Animals in Sport and Entertainment | newspaper = | pages = | year = | date = | url =http://www.animalliberation.org.au/sport.php }}</ref> and by political parties such as The Greens.<ref>{{Citation | last =Pennicuik | first =Sue | title =Sue Pennicuik calls for jumps racing to be banned now once and for all | newspaper = | pages = | date =2009-05-07 | url =http://mps.vic.greens.org.au/node/1105 }}</ref>
==Eventing== The equestrian sport of [[eventing]] had a steeplechase phase, which was held in its CCI 3 Day event format. This phase is called cross country phase B when in the context of eventing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehorse.com/articles/15205/eventings-short-and-long-formats-compared|website=thehorse.com|accessdate=9 October 2017|title=Eventing's Short and Long Formats Compared|date=June 2005}}</ref> There was a roads and tracks phase, a steeplechase phase, a second, faster roads and track phase and finally the cross country jumps course. Now only the cross country jumps course remains (changes were due to space required for the additional courses and logistics). Unlike the racing form, which is far closer to the sport of hunting, the horses do not race each other over the course, but rather are required to come within a pre-set "optimum time period." Penalty points are added to the competitor's score if they exceed or come in well under the optimum time.<ref name="Three Day Events - Rules; Specifications for Three-Day Events">{{cite book|title=USEF Rules for Eventing (2016)|date=2016|publisher=United States Equestrian Federation/Master Print, Inc.|pages=63–66, Appendix 8|url=http://useventing.com/sites/default/files/USEA_2016_RuleBook_5.6.pdf|accessdate=9 October 2017}}</ref> While phase B obstacles are similar to those found on actual steeplechase courses, the [[cross country obstacles]] for phase D are usually extremely varied, some being topped with brush as in steeplechasing, others being solid, others are into and out of water and others are over ditches. There are often combinations of several fences to test the horse's agility. The variety in obstacles is used to make the horse demonstrate agility, power, intelligence, and bravery. The long format was phased out at the FEI level between 2003<ref>{{cite web|last1=Wofford|first1=Jim|title=Jim Wofford: Short Format "Dumbs Down" Eventing|url=https://practicalhorsemanmag.com/training/short_format_122308|website=Practical Horseman|publisher=Practical Horseman|accessdate=10 October 2017}}</ref> and 2008,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.chronofhorse.com/forum/forum/discussion-forums/eventing/27716-fei-set-to-remove-all-reference-to-long-format-cci-in-2009|title=FEI set to remove all reference to long format CCI in 2009 -
Chronicle Forums|website=www.chronofhorse.com}}</ref> but several countries continue to run long format events at the national level, including the US,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Nicora|first1=Stephanie|title=Long Format Alive and Well in USEA Classic Series|url=http://eventingnation.com/long-format-alive-and-well-in-usea-classic-series/|website=Eventing Nation|accessdate=10 October 2017}}</ref> Great Britain,<ref>{{cite web|title=Why You Should Enter the Aldon BE1003DE|url=http://e-venting.co.uk/2016/03/why-you-should-enter-the-aldon-be1003de/|website=e-Venting|accessdate=10 October 2017|date=2016-03-16}}</ref> and Canada.<ref>{{cite web|title=Oakhurst 3DE|url=http://www.oakhurstfarm.com/Oakhurst3DE|website=Oakhurst Farm|accessdate=10 October 2017}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Horse racing}} * [[American Grand National]] * [[Breeders' Cup Grand National Steeplechase]] * [[Cheltenham Festival]] * [[Cheltenham Gold Cup]] * [[Grand National]] * [[Henry Alken|Henry Alken, Famous painter of steeple chases]] * [[List of horse races]] * [[National Hunt Chase Challenge Cup]] * [[National Hunt racing]] * [[Point-to-point (steeplechase)]] * [[Velká pardubická]]

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = The Northern Echo Arena | fullname = | image = Darlington arena 003.jpg | caption = The arena as pictured in 2009 | location = [[Darlington]], England | former_names = | opened = 2003 | owner = [[Darlington Mowden Park R.F.C.|Darlington Mowden Park]] | operator = | surface = Grass | capacity = 25,500{{cite web |url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/clubs/20090621/darlington_2246559_693028 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100323053312/http://www.football-league.co.uk/clubs/20090621/darlington_2246559_693028 |title=Darlington |publisher=The Football League |archivedate=23 March 2010}}{{cite web |url=http://www.darlington.gov.uk/dar_public/Document%20Library/Development%20and%20Environment/Development%20and%20Regeneration/Planning%20Services/Projects/DFC/PlanningStatement.pdf |archive-url=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20110928020821/http://www.darlington.gov.uk/dar_public/Document%20Library/Development%20and%20Environment/Development%20and%20Regeneration/Planning%20Services/Projects/DFC/PlanningStatement.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-09-28 |format=PDF |title=Planning Statement |page=18 |date=May 2007 |author=Ward Hadaway for Darlington Football Club |publisher=Darlington Borough Council }} | tenants = [[Darlington F.C.]] (2003–2012)
[[Darlington Mowden Park R.F.C.]] (2012–) | seating_capacity = 25,000 | dimensions = {{convert|110|×|74|yards|m|0}} | cost = £18 million{{cite web|url=https://www.footballgroundmap.com/ground/the-darlington-arena/darlington|title=The Darlington Arena, former home to Darlington|work=Football Ground Map|accessdate=31 December 2017}} }} '''The Northern Echo Arena''' is a [[rugby union]] and former [[Soccer-specific stadium|football stadium]], located in [[Darlington]], [[County Durham]]. The arena was opened in the summer of 2003, as the new home ground of [[Darlington F.C.]], following the decision to leave their previous ground, [[Feethams]], after the [[2002–03 in English football|2002–03 season]]. With a [[seating capacity]] of 25,000, the arena rarely attracted large audiences, with the usual attendance being around 2,000. The cost of the arena caused the club to go into administration three times. Eventually, the club decided to leave the arena after nine years following the [[2011–12 in English football|2011–12 season]]. In December 2012, after rumours that the arena could be closed down and be replaced with different reported purposes, rugby union team, [[Darlington Mowden Park RFC]] purchased the arena for £2 million; the owner of the club later stated that he believed that the arena could lead to much more success for the club. ==History== {{multiple image |direction=vertical |image1=Darlington arena 002.jpg |caption1=Ground showing the words "Come on Darlo" |width= |alt1= |image2=Darlington arena 001.jpg |caption2=The arena in April 2009 |width2= |alt2= }} Prior to moving to the ground in 2003, [[Darlington F.C.]] had been playing at [[Feethams]], located near to the town centre. The current stadium was built on a greenfield site next to Darlington's [[A66 road|A66 bypass]]. Upon completion the arena was originally called the '''Reynolds Arena''', after the club's then owner, [[George Reynolds (business)|George Reynolds]]. After Reynolds' bankruptcy and arrest on charges of [[money laundering]], the name was changed to the '''New Stadium''' in April 2004. The Arena consists of four equally sided stands. The West Stand, located behind the goal, was generally the more vocal of the two sides used by home supporters. A crowd of 11,600 watched the first game in the new stadium for a 2–0 defeat to [[Kidderminster Harriers F.C.|Kidderminster Harriers]].{{cite news |title=Darlington 0–2 Kidderminster |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_3/3137569.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 August 2003 |accessdate=8 December 2012}} Since then, the ground averaged a gate of around 1,500 to 2,000 supporters, although certain fixtures such as the derby match defeat against local rivals [[Hartlepool United F.C.|Hartlepool United]] in March 2007 (10,121 spectators), pulled in a significantly larger turnout. {{citation needed|date=April 2016}} The club has sold the naming rights for the stadium to various sponsors: Williamson Motors, 96.6 TFM, Balfour Webnet, and in 2009 ''[[The Northern Echo]]''; since [[Darlington Mowden Park RFC]] have used the arena, it has been named ''The Northern Echo Arena'', rather than the previous name ''The Northern Echo Darlington Arena''. It was the largest [[Conference National]] venue with a capacity of 25,000. Attendances for football matches were restricted to 10,000 by local planning regulations, because of poor access roads around the stadium, although the club was allowed to apply for an exception for special occasions. It was announced in May 2012 that Darlington would no longer play at the Darlington Arena, with the club later folding and being replaced by a new club – [[Darlington 1883]]. The club initially agreed a ground share deal with [[Shildon A.F.C.]],{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17990221|title=Darlington seal groundshare deal with Shildon AFC|date=8 May 2012|accessdate=8 December 2012|publisher=BBC Sport}} before deciding to share with [[Bishop Auckland F.C.]] instead.{{cite news |url=http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/news/9736049.QUAKERS_LATEST__Darlington_to_play_at_Bishop_Auckland__not_Shildon/ |title=Darlington to play at Bishop Auckland, not Shildon |first=Joe |last=Willis |work=The Northern Echo |date=30 May 2012 |accessdate=8 December 2012}} Following the announcement that the football club would no longer play at the arena, it was reported that the arena may be closed down and be replaced by a housing estate. However, in December 2012, [[Darlington Mowden Park R.F.C.]] bought the arena for £2 million, as well as {{convert|17|acres}} of adjoining land, with the intention of developing a multi-sports facility; the club owner stated that he hoped that playing at the arena would improve Mowden Park's performances.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/rugby-union/20626002 |title=Darlington Mowden Park: Rugby team buy The Arena |publisher=BBC SEport |date=6 December 2012 |accessdate=8 December 2012}} This would be proved to be true, as they were promoted to [[National League 1]], the third tier of English rugby union, beginning in the [[2014–15 National League 1|2014–15 season]].{{cite web | url=http://www.mowdenpark.com/news/dmprfc-30--ampthill-rfc-28-1213914.html | title=DMPRFC 30 – Ampthill RFC 28 | publisher=DMP | first=Andy | last = Craggs | date=3 May 2014 | accessdate=9 May 2014}} The club played their first game at the arena on 2 February 2013, in front of a crowd of over 1,000 spectators, defeating [[Bromsgrove RFC|Bromsgrove]] 62–7 in a [[National League 2 North]] league game.{{cite web|url=http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/sport/rugby/local/10203133.MATCH_REPORT__Darlington_Mowden_Park_62_Bromsgrove_7/ |title=Darlington Mowden Park make dream start at Northern Echo Arena |publisher=The Northern Echo |date=2 February 2013 }} Regular attendances would bring in around 700–1,300 spectators. ==Other uses== The Arena also played host to the first professional [[rugby league]] match to be played in [[County Durham]], when [[Newcastle Thunder|Gateshead Thunder]] used the ground for their fifth round [[2009 Challenge Cup]] game against [[Oldham R.L.F.C.|Oldham]] due to a fixture clash.{{cite news |url=http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/sport/4355805.Super_League_dream_for_Thunder_supremo_Findlay/ |title=Super League dream for Thunder supremo Findlay |first=Scott |last=Wilson |work=The Northern Echo |date=9 May 2009 |accessdate=9 December 2012}} ===Concerts=== Darlington planned to use the stadium for musical concerts to increase club revenue. [[Elton John]] was the first act to play at the stadium, on 5 July 2008, attracting a crowd of 17,000.{{cite news |url=http://www.darlingtonandstocktontimes.co.uk/sport/9690713.What_next_for_the_Darlington_Arena_/ |title=What next for the Darlington Arena? |first=Stuart |last=Arnold |work=Darlington and Stockton Times |date=5 May 2012|accessdate=9 December 2012}} In November 2017, it was announced that [[A-ha]] and [[Steps (group)|Steps]], with [[Aqua (band)|Aqua]] and [[Blue (English band)|Blue]] as Steps' opening acts, would perform at the stadium in 2018.http://www.gazettelive.co.uk/whats-on/music-nightlife-news/ha-steps-aqua-blue-play-13898293 {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" |- ! Act ! Date(s) ! Attendance |- |[[Elton John]] |5 July 2008 |17,000 |- |[[Steps (group)|Steps]] |27 May 2018 |{{TableTBA}} |- |[[A-ha]] |17 June 2018 |{{TableTBA}} |- |} ==References== {{Commonscat|Darlington Arena}} {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://www.footballgroundmap.com/ground/the-darlington-arena/darlington/ The Darlington Arena] at Football Ground Map {{Darlington F.C.}} {{coord|54|30|30.33|N|1|32|3.82|W|region:GB|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Darlington Arena, The}} [[Category:Defunct football venues in England]] [[Category:Rugby union stadiums in England]] [[Category:Darlington F.C.]] [[Category:Sports venues in County Durham]] [[Category:Sport in Darlington (borough)]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2003]] [[Category:English Football League venues]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2016}} {{Use British English|date=June 2016}} {{Infobox film | name = Twenty Four Seven | image = TwentyFourSevenMovie.jpg | caption = UK DVD cover | director = [[Shane Meadows]] | producer = Imogen West | writer = Paul Fraser
Shane Meadows | starring = [[Bob Hoskins]] | music = [[Boo Hewerdine]]
Neil MacColl | cinematography = Ashley Rowe | editing = [[William Diver]] | studio = [[BBC Films]] | distributor = [[Pathé|Guild Pathé Cinema]] | released = '''Canada:'''
10 September 1997
'''United Kingdom:'''
3 April 1998 | runtime = 96 minutes | country = United Kingdom | language = English | budget = | gross = $72,544{{cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movie/24-7-Twenty-Four-Seven#tab=summary|title=24 7: Twenty Four Seven (1998)|work=The Numbers}} }} '''''Twenty Four Seven''''' is a 1997 British [[Sports film|sports]] [[Drama (film and television)|drama film]] directed and written by [[Shane Meadows]]. It was co-written by frequent Meadows collaborator Paul Fraser. ==Plot== In a typical English working-class town, the juveniles have nothing more to do than hang around in gangs. One day, Alan Darcy ([[Bob Hoskins]]), a highly motivated man with the same kind of youth experience, starts trying to get the young people off the street and into doing something they can believe in; boxing. Soon, he opens a training facility which is accepted gratefully by them and the gangs start to grow together into friends. Darcy manages to organise a public fight for them to prove what they have learned. A training camp with hiking tours into the mountains of Wales forge the group into a tightly-knit club society. With the day of the fight drawing closer, the young boxers get more and more excited. ==Cast== * [[Bob Hoskins]] as Alan Darcy * Danny Nussbaum as Tim * [[Justin Brady]] as Gadget * [[James Hooton]] as Wolfman Knighty * Darren O. Campbell as Daz * [[Karl Collins]] as Stuart * Johann Myers as Benny * Jimmy Hynd as Meggy * Mat Hand as Wesley Fagash * [[James Corden]] as Tonka * [[Frank Harper]] as Ronnie Marsh * [[Bruce Jones (actor)|Bruce Jones]] as Tim's Dad * Jo Bell as Jo ==Reception== The film received very favourable press on release in the UK, including five star reviews from publications including ''[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]]''. It subsequently performed well at UK awards ceremonies. At the 1998 [[BAFTA Awards]], it was nominated for the Alexander Korda Award for Best British Film. At the 1998 [[British Independent Film Awards]], Meadows won the Douglas Hickox Award and the film was nominated in the Best British Independent Film category. Meadows won the [[FIPRESCI]] Prize at the 1998 [[Venice Film Festival]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|id=0120391|title=24 7: Twenty Four Seven}} * {{Rotten Tomatoes|twentyfourseven}} {{Shane Meadows}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Twenty Four Seven}} [[Category:1990s sports films]] [[Category:1997 films]] [[Category:BBC Films films]] [[Category:Boxing films]] [[Category:British black-and-white films]] [[Category:British films]] [[Category:British sports films]] [[Category:British teen drama films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films directed by Shane Meadows]] [[Category:Films set in Nottingham]] [[Category:Films shot in Cheshire]] [[Category:Films shot in Derbyshire]] [[Category:Films shot in Nottinghamshire]] [[Category:Sports drama films]] [[Category:Teen sports films]] {{1990s-UK-film-stub}}

{{Football club infobox | clubname = US Baie-Mahault | image = US Baie-Mahault.png | fullname = Union Sportive Baie-Mahaultienne | nickname = | founded = | ground = [[Stade Fiesque Duchesne]],
[[Baie-Mahault]], [[Guadeloupe]] | capacity = | chairman = {{flagicon|Guadeloupe|local}} [[Anatole Mimiette]] | manager = {{flagicon|Guadeloupe|local}} [[Eddy Gueppois]] | league = [[Promotion d'Honneur Régionale]] | season = 2009/10 | position = 13th (relegated) | pattern_la1=|pattern_b1=_blueshoulders|pattern_ra1= | leftarm1=FFFFFF|body1=FFFFFF|rightarm1=FFFFFF|shorts1=FFFFFF|socks1=FFFFFF }} '''US Baie-Mahault''' is a [[football (soccer)|football]] club in [[Guadeloupe]], based in the town of [[Baie-Mahault]]. They play in Guadeloupe's second division, the [[Promotion d'Honneur Régionale]]. ==Achievements== *'''[[Coupe de Guadeloupe]]: 1''' :: 1988 ==External links== * [http://usbm-footeo.footeo.com/index.php?module=footeo_kernel Official website] – US Baie-Mahault * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090109162345/http://foot2gwada.blogs.francefootball.com/effectifs_des_clubs_de_dh/ Tour des clubs 2008–2009] – Gwadafoot {{fr|icon}} * [http://www.fff.fr/competitions/php/club/club_fiche.php?cl_no=5515 Club info] – French Football Federation {{fr|icon}} {{Guadeloupe Division d’Honneur}} [[Category:Football clubs in Guadeloupe|Baie]] {{Guadeloupe-footyclub-stub}}

{{distinguish|Warrior (shoes)}} {{Infobox company |name= Warrior Sports |logo= Warrior Sports logo.svg |logo_size= 250px |caption= |type= [[Subsidiary]] |traded_as= |fate= |predecessor= |successor= |foundation= {{Start date and age|1992}} |founder= [[David Morrow (sports)|David Morrow]]{{cite news |url= http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Daily/Issues/2011/03/17/People-and-Pop-Culture/What-I-Like.aspx |title= What I Like.... with Warrior Sports Founder, President & CEO Dave Morrow |work= SportBusiness Daily |date= March 17, 2011}} |location_city= [[Warren, Michigan]] |location_country= United States |location= |locations= |area_served= [[North America]], [[Europe]], [[Asia]] |key_people= David Morrow
(President & CEO) |industry= [[Sporting goods]] |products= [[Sportswear (activewear)|Sportswear]], [[sports equipment]] |services= |revenue= |operating_income= |net_income= |assets= |equity= |owner= |num_employees= |parent= [[New Balance]] |divisions= |subsid= |homepage= {{URL|http://www.warrior.com}} |footnotes= |intl= }} [[File:Finale de la coupe de France de Hockey sur glace 2013 - 032bis.jpg|thumb|Ice hockey stick]] '''Warrior Sports''' is an American manufacturer of [[lacrosse]], [[ice hockey]] and [[association football|soccer]] equipment and [[clothing]] based in [[Warren, Michigan]]. Warrior entered the soccer market in 2012, producing [[jersey (clothing)|kit]]s and training equipment for several clubs around the world, although the soccer sponsorship and products were later discontinued with its parent company [[New Balance]]'s entry into the category. ==History== Warrior Sports was founded in 1992 by [[David Morrow (sports)|David Morrow]], a former lacrosse player. The company name is derived from Morrow's roots as a member of the Brother Rice Lacrosse team, the Warriors, in [[Birmingham, Michigan]]. The company started out as the first manufacturer of titanium lacrosse shafts, which changed the game due to their strength and light weight.{{citation needed|date=January 2015}} Morrow went on to highlight the breakthrough shaft as he played for the Princeton Tigers lacrosse team. He also went on to be the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] player of the year. In 2004, the [[privately held company]], [[New Balance|New Balance Athletic Shoe, Inc.]] obtained controlling interest in Warrior. One year later, Warrior moved into the [[ice hockey]] industry when it acquired [[California]]–based manufacturer Innovative Hockey.{{cite web |title=About Warrior |url=http://www.warrior.com/company-info/about |publisher=Warrior Sports |access-date= May 24, 2011}}{{cite web |title=Warrior History |url=http://www.warrior.com/company-info/history |publisher=Warrior Sports |access-date= May 24, 2011}} In 2007 Warrior acquired the Boston-based Brine Sporting Goods to further establish their market share in lacrosse.https://www.warrior.com/about-us.html ==Controversy== Beginning in July 2012, Warrior Lacrosse embroiled itself in controversy by launching a Twitter marketing campaign for which users were entered into a raffle to win a free pair of shoes if they used the [[hashtag]] #ninjaplease. The campaign has been widely derided throughout the industry and in the lacrosse world. As Warrior was a founding factor in Major League Lacrosse (MLL) and sponsors all teams, some African-American players in the league have protested, with the possibility of retiring from the league should the controversy not be handled appropriately. Warrior suspended the campaign and the MLL removed all references to it on October 29, 2012, when the meaning of the hashtag used in the campaign came to the attention of officials of both organizations.{{cite web|last= Wilson |first= Connor|title=When Marketing Goes Awry: #NinjaPlease|url=http://laxallstars.com/when-marketing-goes-awry-ninjaplease/|publisher=Lacrosse All Stars|date= November 9, 2012}}{{cite news |last= Foy |first= Terry |title= Jovan Miller, Warrior Respond to 'Dojo' Campaign, Mainstream Media Attention |url= http://insidelacrosse.com/ilgear/news/2012/11/09/jovan-miller-warrior-respond-dojo-campaign-mainstream-media-attention |work= Inside Lacrosse |date= November 9, 2012}} ==Sponsorships== [[File:Liverpool FC team v FC Gomel.jpg|thumb|[[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]]'s first-team wearing the 2012–13 season home kit made by Warrior]] In April 2011, Warrior Sports reportedly signed a sponsorship agreement for [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] worth [[Pound sign|£]]25 million per season as of the 2012–13 season while [[Carlsberg Group|Carlsberg]] reduced their annual sponsorship to just half of that, overtaking the English club record of £23.3 million paid by [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] for supplying [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] and the previous deal from [[Adidas]] worth £13 million.{{cite news |title= Liverpool's Mammoth £25m-a-Year Warrior Kit Deal Rewrites the Record Books |url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1379466/Liverpools-mammoth-25m-year-Warrior-kit-deal-rewrites-record-books.html |work= [[The Daily Mail]] |access-date= May 25, 2011 |location=London|date= April 22, 2011}}{{cite news |last= Abelson |first= Jenn |date= April 23, 2011 |title= New Balance Unit in Deal with Liverpool FC |url= http://www.boston.com/business/articles/2011/04/23/new_balance_unit_in_deal_with_liverpool_fc/ |work= Boston.com |access-date= January 17, 2015}}{{cite news |last= Harris |first= Rob |date= May 13, 2011 |title= Liverpool Plans to Reclaim Record from Manchester United |url= http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/soccer/2011-05-13-2687927294_x.htm |work= [[USA Today]] |agency= [[Associated Press]] |access-date= January 17, 2015}} On January 18, 2012, Liverpool and Warrior Sports announced a deal between the two organisations, whereby Warrior became the Liverpool kit sponsor effective from June 1, 2012.{{cite news |title= Liverpool Signs New Kit Deal with US firm Warrior |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-16627867 |publisher= [[BBC News]] |access-date= January 19, 2012 |date= January 19, 2012}} The new Liverpool home kits were launched on the official Liverpool website on May 11, 2012, and were notable for their classic design and a return to a more simplified club badge.{{cite web |title=Our New Home Kit for 2012—13 |url= http://www.liverpoolfc.tv/news/latest-news/our-new-home-kit-for-2012-13 |publisher= Liverpool FC |access-date= May 11, 2012 |date= May 11, 2012}} The design was welcomed by most fans but has angered some. This is due to the new kit moving the traditional commemorative symbol for the [[Hillsborough disaster]] from the front to the back of the kit.{{cite news|title= Liverpool Kit Launch Sparks Anger Among Hillsborough Families |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18033752 |publisher= BBC Sport |access-date= May 11, 2012|date= May 11, 2012}} On June 5, 2013, the new Liverpool [[away kit]] was launched for the 2013–14 season. Described as "possibly one of the worst [[Kit (association football)|football kits]] of all time",{{cite web |url= http://blog.foxsoccer.com/post/52094489459/liverpool-new-kits-should-already-win-worst-of-the-year |title= Liverpool New Kits Should Already Win Worst of the Year |department= FOX Soccer Blog |work= FOX Sports on MSN |date= |access-date= August 16, 2014}} its reception was overwhelmingly negative, both in the press{{cite news |first= Jamie |last= Sanderson |url= http://metro.co.uk/2013/06/04/liverpool-kit-leak-horrendous-away-and-third-choice-kits-for-20132014-revealed-3827651/ |title= Liverpool Kit Leak: 'Horrendous' Away and Third-Choice Kits for 2013/2014 Revealed and Slammed by Fans on Twitter |work= Metro News |date= June 4, 2013 |access-date= August 16, 2014}}{{cite news |last=Curtis |first= Ben |url= https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/new-liverpool-away-kit-design-1932691 |title= New Liverpool Away Kit Design: Merseyside Club Unveil Latest Strip for 2013/14 season |work= The Mirror |location= |date= June 5, 2013 |access-date= August 16, 2014}}{{cite web |url= http://www.theweek.co.uk/football/53421/liverpool-away-kit-unveiled-why-suarez-wants-quit |title= Liverpool Away Kit Unveiled: Is This Why Luis Suarez Wants to Quit? |work= The Week UK |date= June 5, 2013 |access-date= August 16, 2014}}{{cite web |author= |url= http://whatculture.com/sport/liverpool-new-201314-kits-revealed-theyre-awful.php |title= Liverpool: New 2013/14 Kits Revealed & They're Awful |work= Whatculture.com |date= February 10, 2013 |access-date= August 16, 2014}} and from the fans, who quickly took to social media{{cite web |author= |url= http://damianpriday.com/tag/warrior-football/ |title= Warrior Football |work= Damianpriday.com |date= June 5, 2013 |access-date= August 16, 2014}} to express their dislike of it. In February 2015, parent company New Balance announced it was entering the global soccer market. As part of the move, all clubs and players sponsored by Warrior would be outfitted by New Balance while Warrior would go back to just hockey and lacrosse going forward.{{cite news |title= New Balance Challenges Nike and Adidas with Entry into Global Soccer Market |url= https://www.forbes.com/sites/kurtbadenhausen/2015/02/04/new-balance-enters-global-soccer-market/ |first= Kurt |last= Badenhausen |work= Forbes |date= February 4, 2015|access-date= February 4, 2015}} The practice facility of the [[Boston Bruins]] of the [[National Hockey League]] and the home arena of the [[Boston Pride]] of the [[National Women's Hockey League (2015)|National Women's Hockey League]] is named [[Warrior Ice Arena]]. The arena, part of a larger project called Boston Landing is owned by Warrior's parent company New Balance. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Warrior Sports}} * {{official website}} * [http://www.warriorfootball.com Warrior Football] [[Category:New Balance]] [[Category:Lacrosse equipment]] [[Category:Ice hockey brands]] [[Category:Sporting goods manufacturers of the United States]] [[Category:Sportswear brands]] [[Category:Warren, Michigan]] [[Category:Companies based in Macomb County, Michigan]] [[Category:Companies established in 1992]]
